results.headline: Finding Love in a Cruel Time
results.summary_short: In “The Pin,” Naomi Jaye tells a tale of two young Eastern Europeans hiding in a barn during World War II and creates a mood of unadulterated romance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pin

results.headline: Troubles in the Kitchen
results.summary_short: “Spinning Plates” portrays the challenges faced by the proprietors of three very different restaurants.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spinning Plates

results.headline: Fishing as Therapy
results.summary_short: “Not Yet Begun to Fight” shows combat veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan undergoing an unusual form of therapy: fly-fishing as regenerative meditation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Not Yet Begun to Fight

results.headline: Murder, Mayhem and Cross-Dressing Zombies
results.summary_short: The Filipino horror comedy “Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings” features zombie drag queens, a gay curse and a serial killer with a gaydar gun.
results.display_title: Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings

results.headline: Being Gay in Lebanon
results.summary_short: “Out Loud,” from Samer Daboul, is a film from Lebanon engaging the taboo: homosexuality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Out Loud

results.headline: Crudely Closing a Generation Gap
results.summary_short: Johnny Knoxville’s latest prankfest has him portraying 86-year-old Irving Zisman on a cross-country trip with an 8-year-old grandson named Billy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa

results.headline: A Geriatric Biker Gang
results.summary_short: “Go Grandriders” follows a gang of elderly motor scooter riders as they try to circumnavigate Taiwan on its scenic and crowded coastal roads.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Go Grandriders

results.headline: Incalculable Loss, Inconsolable Mother
results.summary_short: Postpartum depression takes a homicidal turn in Le-Van Kiet’s “House in the Alley.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of House in the Alley

results.headline: So Evil, They Cackle at Strategy Meetings
results.summary_short: “Capital,” directed by Costa-Gavras, centers on the machinations of ruthless financiers during a takeover attempt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Capital

results.headline: On the Road With the Vienna Boys Choir
results.summary_short: Curt Faudon’s “Bridging the Gap” chronicles the Vienna Boys Choir’s cross-cultural journeys.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bridging the Gap

results.headline: Families, and Money, With More Than One Complication
results.summary_short: The director Claire Denis returns to Paris for her new film, “Bastards,” starring Vincent Lindon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bastards

results.headline: Standing Up for Muslims in India’s Courts
results.summary_short: “Shahid” is a fictionalized biopic about the life and death of Shahid Azmi, a lawyer who frequently represented Muslims in India’s courts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shahid

results.headline: Where Love Coexists With Death
results.summary_short: A documentary by a first-time filmmaker, Steve Hoover, about a friend who finds his life’s work at a home for H.I.V.-positive children in India.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood Brother

results.headline: The Strong, Largely Silent Type
results.summary_short: In J. C. Chandor’s “All Is Lost,” Robert Redford is a sailor adrift in the Indian Ocean.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All Is Lost

results.headline: Have I Got a Movie for You
results.summary_short: The documentary “Seduced and Abandoned” follows two friends at the Cannes Film Festival as they try to find a buyer for a sexually explosive movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seduced and Abandoned

results.headline: The Blood and Tears, Not the Magnolias
results.summary_short: Steve McQueen’s “12 Years a Slave,” based on the true story of Solomon Northup, drives straight to the heart of the cruelties of oppression.

results.headline: Two Mothers, Divided by Their Sons
results.summary_short: In “Torn,” an explosion at a mall leads to questions about two teenagers killed in the blast and our own prejudices.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Torn

results.headline: Remembering Pillars of Israel’s Past
results.summary_short: The documentary “The Prime Ministers,” which is being released in two parts, profiles Golda Meier and other leaders of Israel from the 1940s to the ’70s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Prime Ministers:The Pioneers

results.headline: Making Cities Work for People
results.summary_short: “The Human Scale” looks at ways to turn urban areas into better places to live.

results.headline: Seems This Anarchist Is a Laptop Hogger
results.summary_short: “The Fifth Estate,” about the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, documents the ups and downs of his relationship with a onetime colleague.
